items.title: China signals global AI push as MiniMax CEO joins meeting with Premier Li Qiang
items.creator: Vincent Chow,Xinyi Wu

items.translated_title: China signals global AI push as MiniMax CEO joins meeting with Premier Li Qiang

images.alt: The appearance of MiniMax founder Yan Junjie (second from right) along with other leading figures underscored the rapid ascent of the newly minted billionaire. Photo: CCTV
images.title: The appearance of MiniMax founder Yan Junjie (second from right) along with other leading figures underscored the rapid ascent of the newly minted billionaire. Photo: CCTV

items.content:
The CEO of Chinese artificial intelligence company MiniMax met Premier Li Qiang on Monday, becoming the second representative from a foundational AI model developer to meet with the national leader after Liang Wenfeng, founder of DeepSeek, a year ago.
The appearance of 36-year-old Yan Junjie along with eight other leading figures from China’s business, culture and education spheres underscored the rapid ascent of the newly minted billionaire, who steered his company founded just four years ago...

items.title: DeepSeek technique to improve AI’s ability to ‘read’ long texts questioned by new research
items.creator: Ben Jiang
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: DeepSeek technique to improve AI’s ability to ‘read’ long texts questioned by new research

images.alt: A DeepSeek display at an AI fair in Hangzhou, east China’s Zhejiang Province, May 4, 2025. Photo: Xinhua
images.title: A DeepSeek display at an AI fair in Hangzhou, east China’s Zhejiang Province, May 4, 2025. Photo: Xinhua

items.content:
A group of researchers from China and Japan has challenged a method unveiled several months ago by Chinese artificial intelligence start-up DeepSeek that was designed to improve AI’s ability to handle long blocks of text, marking a rare case of the company’s research being publicly questioned.
The DeepSeek-OCR (optical character recognition) method, designed to compress text by using visual representations, potentially revolutionising how AI models handle long texts, was flawed due to...

items.title: China’s nuclear fusion start-ups power up with record funding round
items.creator: Eunice Xu
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: China’s nuclear fusion start-ups power up with record funding round

images.alt: The Compact Fusion Experimental Facility is under construction in Hefei in this photo taken on November 24, 2025. Photo: Xinhua
images.title: The Compact Fusion Experimental Facility is under construction in Hefei in this photo taken on November 24, 2025. Photo: Xinhua

items.content:
China’s pursuit of commercial nuclear fusion technology has intensified this year, fuelled by a fresh round of financing for start-ups and state-backed initiatives.
Startorus Fusion last week raised 1 billion yuan (US$143 million) from its series A round, a record for a single financing round by a private nuclear fusion company on the mainland, according to a report by the Securities Times.
The deal, announced on January 12, was led by state-owned funds in Shanghai, which contributed around 400...

items.title: China challenges US in AI drug race, but rivals still reliant on each other
items.creator: Julie Zhang

items.translated_title: China challenges US in AI drug race, but rivals still reliant on each other

images.alt: Chinese biotech firms are working with global pharmaceutical firms to commercialise their drugs in international markets. Photo: Shutterstock
images.title: Chinese biotech firms are working with global pharmaceutical firms to commercialise their drugs in international markets. Photo: Shutterstock

items.content:
China has emerged as a credible challenger to the US in artificial intelligence-driven drug discovery, where advantage depends not only on computing prowess but also on the ability to effectively mine data, from genomes to clinical trial results, according to Leung Chuen-yan, a private equity investor and life sciences scientist.
“Globally, the way companies develop and use AI to discover drugs is similar, from finding the drug target and designing the molecule to planning clinical trials,” said...

items.title: Chinese-owned Temu catches up with Amazon in global cross-border e-commerce
items.creator: Coco Feng

items.translated_title: Chinese-owned Temu catches up with Amazon in global cross-border e-commerce

images.alt: The Amazon logo is seen at the company logistics centre in Boves, France, August 8, 2018. Photo: Reuters
images.title: The Amazon logo is seen at the company logistics centre in Boves, France, August 8, 2018. Photo: Reuters

items.content:
In a seismic shift for the global retail landscape, Temu, the budget shopping platform owned by PDD Holdings, has caught up with Amazon.com in cross-border market share globally.
The platform, which launched in 2022, saw its share surge from less than 1 per cent then to 24 per cent last year, on par with American giant Amazon, according to a survey published by International Post Corporation (IPC), an association of 26 national postal services in Europe, Asia-Pacific and North America.
Amazon’s...

images.title: Dr Li Linxian, Founder and CEO of Innorna, spent over 16 years advancing LNP research across Germany, the US, Hong Kong, and Mainland China,

items.content:
[The content of this article has been produced by our advertising partner.]
 
Since their emergency-use rollout in late 2020, billions of doses of COVID 19 vaccines built on disruptive mRNA technology have been administered worldwide, saving hundreds of millions of lives. Now, the global pharmaceutical industry is pushing far beyond next generation vaccines. Companies worldwide are rapidly expanding into mRNA based therapeutics aimed at chronic and autoimmune diseases, rare genetic disorders,...

items.title: DeepSeek a year on: how a little-known Chinese start-up sparked a global AI arms race
items.creator: Ben Jiang
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: DeepSeek a year on: how a little-known Chinese start-up sparked a global AI arms race

images.alt: Industry experts said DeepSeek’s impact for China goes beyond technology. Photo: DigiTimes
images.title: Industry experts said DeepSeek’s impact for China goes beyond technology. Photo: DigiTimes

items.content:
One year ago, a little-known Chinese start-up called DeepSeek burst onto the scene with a new artificial intelligence model that challenged assumptions about China’s ability to innovate under US technology curbs.
In what became known as the “DeepSeek moment”, the Hangzhou-based firm kicked off what some likened as a modern-day “Sputnik moment” for China’s AI ambitions.
Just as the Soviet Union’s 1957 launch of Sputnik, the world’s first artificial satellite, shocked the US and triggered the...

items.title: China’s Unitree ships more than 5,500 humanoid robots in 2025, surpassing US peers
items.creator: Iris Deng,Coco Feng,Wency Chen
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: China’s Unitree ships more than 5,500 humanoid robots in 2025, surpassing US peers
items.content:
China’s Unitree Robotics shipped more than 5,500 humanoid robots in 2025, according to a person with knowledge of the matter, as the Hangzhou-based company ramped up production ahead of its planned listing on the mainland.
That number – covering “pure” full-body, bipedal humanoid models – exceeded those of its American peers such as Tesla, Figure AI and Agility Robotics, which shipped 150 humanoid robots each last year, according to market research firm Omdia.
Unitree saw its annual output...

items.translated_title: Global memory chip crunch set to intensify amid Trump’s new industrial policy

images.alt: US Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick. Photo: EPA
images.title: US Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick. Photo: EPA

items.content:
The shortages and associated price increase in the global memory chip sector could potentially intensify, as the US government threatened to impose hefty new tariffs on some major foreign manufacturers.
Speaking at Friday’s groundbreaking ceremony for Micron Technology’s US$100 billion factory in New York, US Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick warned that memory chipmakers – without naming any company – had two options: “They can pay 100 per cent tariff, or they can build in America.”
He pointed...

items.translated_title: China’s securities regulator clamps down on speculation to prevent sharp market swings

images.alt: AI-related stocks and other emerging technology themes have led the surge in mainland China equities. Photo: Reuters
images.title: AI-related stocks and other emerging technology themes have led the surge in mainland China equities. Photo: Reuters

items.content:
China’s top securities regulator has signalled it wants a slower, longer-lasting stock market rally rather than a short-lived speculative surge as it steps up measures to curb excessive trading after activity and margin financing hit fresh highs early this year.
The stance, reiterated at a securities watchdog meeting last week, drew renewed attention after regulators moved to cool pockets of overheating in the A-share market following a strong start to 2026.
At its January 15 work conference,...

items.title: China’s UBTech partners with Airbus to bring humanoid robots to aviation manufacturing

items.translated_title: China’s UBTech partners with Airbus to bring humanoid robots to aviation manufacturing

images.alt: The Airbus logo is pictured outside the entrance to its campus in Blagnac, France. Photo: AFP
images.title: The Airbus logo is pictured outside the entrance to its campus in Blagnac, France. Photo: AFP

items.content:
Chinese humanoid developer UBTech Robotics has struck a deal to supply European aviation giant Airbus with robots for its manufacturing facilities, the latest step in efforts to expand industrial applications of its robots outside China.
Airbus purchased UBTech’s Walker S2 robot as part of a plan to jointly explore robotics applications in aviation manufacturing, Shenzhen-based UBTech said in a statement on Sunday.
The deal follows a similar partnership last month with US semiconductor maker...

items.title: HKMA unveils 20-point road map to modernise Hong Kong’s trade finance ecosystem

items.translated_title: HKMA unveils 20-point road map to modernise Hong Kong’s trade finance ecosystem

images.alt: Trade is Hong Kong’s second-largest industry after finance, contributing 15 per cent of gross domestic product. Photo: Jelly Tse
images.title: Trade is Hong Kong’s second-largest industry after finance, contributing 15 per cent of gross domestic product. Photo: Jelly Tse

items.content:
The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has unveiled a road map to introduce 20 measures under a five-year initiative aimed at modernising the city’s trade finance landscape and strengthening connectivity with mainland China and Asean trade corridors.
Project CargoX, part of HKMA’s Fintech 2030 strategy, would use blockchain and data to help exporters secure bank loans more easily and strengthen Hong Kong’s role as an international trading hub, said Howard Lee Tat-chi, deputy chief executive of...

items.translated_title: Ant-backed Chinese AI agent developer DeepWisdom aims to help solo entrepreneurs

images.alt: Alex Wu Chenglin, founder and CEO of DeepWisdom. Photo: Handout
images.title: Alex Wu Chenglin, founder and CEO of DeepWisdom. Photo: Handout

items.content:
Chinese AI start-up DeepWisdom, which has launched its Atoms multi-agent application, wants to make life easier for solo entrepreneurs by deploying AI agents to serve in different roles, in what may be a glimpse of the future of work.
“We want everyone to be able to realise their ideas at very low cost,” Alex Wu Chenglin, founder and CEO of DeepWisdom, said in an interview with the Post. “Each person can become one of the building blocks of society.”
Previously known as MGX, Atoms allows users...

items.title: China’s drug and medical device sector emerges as new engine of economic growth

items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: China’s drug and medical device sector emerges as new engine of economic growth

images.alt: Innovative efforts by biotech firms align with Beijing’s ambitions to build China into a technology powerhouse. Photo: Xinhua
images.title: Innovative efforts by biotech firms align with Beijing’s ambitions to build China into a technology powerhouse. Photo: Xinhua

items.content:
China’s pharmaceutical industry, whose revenue is projected to rise by 50 per cent between 2024 and 2030, has emerged as a new growth engine for the national economy as leading players ramp up investment in research and production.
The country’s drug and medical device businesses were forecast to top US$2.1 trillion in revenue by 2030 and US$3.2 trillion annually by 2050, according to estimates by UBS. In 2024, the sector generated about US$1.4 trillion in sales.
“An ageing population offers the...

items.title: China’s tech self-sufficiency powers stock boom and helps it shake off economic malaise
items.creator: Bloomberg
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: China’s tech self-sufficiency powers stock boom and helps it shake off economic malaise
items.content:
Nearly a year after DeepSeek’s AI breakthrough rattled global markets, mainland China is entering 2026 with a fresh wave of technological advances that are powering a stock rally, even as its economy remains fragile.
Thanks to fresh progress in sectors from commercial rockets to robotics and flying cars, Chinese tech shares have begun the new year with a bang. An onshore Nasdaq-like tech gauge has shot up almost 13 per cent so far this month, while a measure of Hong Kong-listed Chinese tech...

items.title: Tencent seeks collaboration with other major AI developers to improve tech for vulnerable users
items.creator: Vincent Chow
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: Tencent seeks collaboration with other major AI developers to improve tech for vulnerable users
items.content:
Researchers at Tencent Holdings are looking to collaborate with other major artificial intelligence developers to improve how most generative AI services, such as chatbots, interact with the elderly, left-behind children and other vulnerable users in society.
Specialised data sets can make AI services more helpful to vulnerable users who have become progressively reliant on them for emotional support and health assistance, according to Lu Shiyu, a senior researcher at Tencent Research Institute...

items.title: Europe’s tech strength lies in deployment, not rivalry
items.creator: Shaoshan Liu
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: Europe’s tech strength lies in deployment, not rivalry
items.content:
Europe’s debate over its technological future is both timely and necessary. The centre of gravity for platform technologies, advanced semiconductors, hyperscale cloud infrastructure and artificial intelligence (AI) has undeniably shifted towards the United States and China.
While the US boasts giants like Microsoft and Nvidia, and China has cultivated powerhouses like Huawei and Tencent, Europe has seen its share of the digital platform market shrink.
However, viewing this shift as inevitable...

items.title: Fighting back: Beijing builds its own ‘small yard, high fence’ to shut out US tech
items.creator: Ben Jiang,Coco Feng,Vincent Chow
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: Fighting back: Beijing builds its own ‘small yard, high fence’ to shut out US tech

images.alt: National security adviser Jake Sullivan speaks during a press briefing at the White House in Washington, D.C., in this file photo dated October 1, 2024. Photo: Abaca Press/TNS
images.title: National security adviser Jake Sullivan speaks during a press briefing at the White House in Washington, D.C., in this file photo dated October 1, 2024. Photo: Abaca Press/TNS

items.content:
“Small yard, high fence” was how Jake Sullivan, national security adviser under President Joe Biden, described US tech policy towards China.
The approach, designed to fence off sensitive US technologies from China, was most commonly associated with export controls that, among others, restricted Chinese firms’ access to Nvidia’s advanced chips, the critical inputs for developing cutting-edge artificial intelligence systems.
Beijing is now fighting back by taking a leaf out of that playbook. For...

items.title: Hong Kong’s pivot to hi-tech development gets boost as city hosts global AI summit
items.creator: Vincent Chow

items.translated_title: Hong Kong’s pivot to hi-tech development gets boost as city hosts global AI summit

images.alt: Photographers are seen snapping pictures of guests at a summit under the World Artificial Intelligence Conference, held at the Hong Kong Science Park on Friday. Photo: AFP
images.title: Photographers are seen snapping pictures of guests at a summit under the World Artificial Intelligence Conference, held at the Hong Kong Science Park on Friday. Photo: AFP

items.content:
Hong Kong took another big step in its journey to become an international tech hub on Friday, as the city basked in its inaugural turn as host of a summit under the World Artificial Intelligence Conference (WAIC).
In his video address to the conference held in the Hong Kong Science Park, Chief Executive John Lee Ka-chiu said: “We must harness the power of AI, not just to innovate, but to build – to build more inclusive economies, more resilient communities and a more sustainable future for...
